header.title: Indonesian Shamanic Methods of Fasting & Austerities

central_thesis: The central thesis posits that fasting and ascetic austerities are fundamental and potent practices within Javanese Kejawen and Indonesian shamanism for cultivating unique occult powers, enhancing psychic abilities, and achieving spiritual attunement. These disciplines systematically transform the practitioner's physical and etheric bodies, mind, and spirit to access higher frequencies and interact with spiritual intelligences, requiring precise timing and dedicated execution.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to Javanese Fasting and Asceticism
structure_content.summary: This section introduces fasting and asceticism as essential practices in Javanese Kejawen and Indonesian shamanism for acquiring unique occult powers. It explains the psychological, biological, and metaphysical effects of fasting, emphasizing its role in raising vibrations, sensitizing the nervous system, and attracting spirit beings. The text highlights the importance of correct timing according to the Javanese calendar.

This part outlines the general conduct during fasting, including refraining from negative thoughts and engaging in spiritual work. It details the importance of affirming intentions, performing ritual cleansing prior to fasts, and adhering to auspicious days and months from the Javanese calendar. It also addresses the common challenges of temptations and visions during these disciplines, viewing them as opportunities for psychological transmutation.

A comprehensive list and description of various Javanese fasting methods are provided, including Mutih (white rice/water), Ngeruh (vegetarian), Ngebleng (complete cessation of activities), Patigeni (extreme seclusion), Ngelowong (lighter fast), Ngrowot (fruitarian), Nganyep (tasteless food), Ngidang (edible leaves), Ngepel (fist-full of rice), Ngasrep (cold, tasteless food), Monday-Thursday Fast, and Wungon (24-hour fast without sleep). Each method specifies dietary restrictions, behavioral rules, and duration.

Beyond dietary fasts, this section details unique physical austerities such as Jejeg (no sitting), Lelana (non-stop walking), Kungkum (ritual river immersion with mantras), Ngalong (inverted meditation/hanging), and Ngeluwang/Nglowong (seclusion in a dug hole). These practices are described with their specific procedures, goals (e.g., breath control, clairvoyance), and associated challenges.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Influence of Islam and Islamic Fasting Types
structure_content.summary: Acknowledging the significant influence of Islam on Javanese mysticism, the article concludes by listing various Islamic fasts. These include the obligatory Ramadan Fast and several non-obligatory fasts such as the Fast of King David, the Three-day Fast, the Six-day Fast, the Arafah-day Fast, the Eighth-day Fast, the Tasu'a and Asura Fast, and the Al-Baidh (Full Moon) Fast, detailing their durations and specific days.

key_concepts.definition: Javanese mysticism, a syncretic spiritual tradition that emphasizes self-mastery, inner wisdom, and connection to the divine, often involving ascetic practices for spiritual and occult development.
A Javanese fast where one consumes only plain white rice (without salt or condiments), plain bread without salt, and plain mineral water, aimed at purification and psychic enhancement.

A severe Javanese austerity requiring complete seclusion in a dark room without food, drink, sleep, or leaving the room for a specified period (e.g., 24 hours, 3, 7 days or more), with waste discharge managed within the room.

A Javanese austerity involving prolonged immersion, often naked, up to the neck in a river mouth where two minor rivers meet, while facing currents. It requires ritual cleansing, specific mantras, and breath control, used for accumulating magickal force.

A challenging Javanese austerity where the practitioner secludes themselves in a large hole dug for the purpose, typically in a graveyard or quiet place, for a designated period (normally 24 hours), aiming to acquire powers like clairvoyance and illusion-casting, accompanied by a specific mantra.
The energetic counterpart to the physical body, which, according to the text, accumulates cosmic power through fasting and appropriate metaphysical exercises, enhancing psychic sensitivity.

A lunar-solar calendar system used in Javanese mysticism to determine auspicious timings, such as specific months (Sura) and days (Kliwon-Tuesday, Legi-Wednesday, Pahing-Thursday), for commencing magical rites and fasting disciplines.

A term describing the instinctual, puerile, and irrational aspect of the physical body that resists and protests against the disciplines of fasting and austerities, manifesting as physical discomfort and mental resistance.

practical_system.description: The practical system is centered on the systematic application of various forms of fasting and physical austerities to induce altered states of consciousness, purify the body and mind, raise vibrational frequencies, accumulate cosmic power in the etheric body, and open channels for communication with spiritual entities. The practices are often linked to the Javanese calendar for optimal timing and require specific preparatory rituals (like cleansing) and mental focus (affirmations, mantras) during execution. The process is expected to confront and transmute inner psychological blockages and lead to the acquisition of specific magical powers like clairvoyance or illusion-casting.

relevant_quotes.text: Fasting as a religio-spiritual practice is known the world over by modern and ancient cultures. Initially, fasting was the result of the inaccessibility of food and proper nourishment in the face of lack and poverty. It was later adopted by the religious/shamanic community for magickal and devotional purposes as it was found to provide certain interesting results psychologically, biologically, and metaphysically.

From the magickal perspective, fasting has an occult effect on both mind and body. Shamanic fasting changes the polarity of the physical body and also raises its vibrations, making it sensitive to the magickal frequencies imperceptible to the five senses.

There is no denying that fasting aids the etheric body to accumulate cosmic power, especially when done in conjunction with the appropriate metaphysical exercises. Without physical nourishment, the body is forced to acquire the energy it needs through some other channels.

Fasting and austerities brings out the worst in us onto the surface--and this is indeed a blessing as we would be made aware of all the neurosis, psychosis, and complexes lurking within the psyche that requires our attention in the art of transmutation.
Niat ingsun nglowong, anutupi badan kang bolong, siro mara sira mati, kang ganggu marang jiwa ingsun, lebur kaya dene banyu krana Allah Ta'ala.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant for practitioners and scholars of Esotericism interested in comparative magic and non-Western traditions. It provides a unique window into the operative aspects of Javanese shamanism, detailing specific ascetic techniques for power acquisition, psychic development, and spiritual purification. Unlike many Western grimoires that focus on ritual tools and invocations, this text emphasizes internal transformation through bodily and mental discipline, aligning with broader occult principles of self-mastery as a prerequisite for effective magic. The detailed descriptions of various fasts and austerities offer concrete methods that can be adapted or studied for their energetic and psychological effects, potentially informing practices within Chaos Magic or Hermeticism by providing alternative means of altering states of consciousness and manipulating subtle energies. It highlights a lesser-documented path to power accumulation, distinct from common ceremonial or folk magic approaches.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience would be advanced practitioners and academic researchers in Esotericism, Occultism, and Comparative Religion who seek to understand and potentially experiment with ascetic disciplines from non-Western shamanic traditions. It would also appeal to individuals interested in self-mastery, psychic development, and energy work through rigorous personal discipline, particularly those exploring Javanese mysticism or cross-cultural magical practices.
